2020-08-01.text: Weird, the original tweet actually DOESNT say that. Like it or not, the word HAS been used as a slur and people HAVE been hurt by it and still are today. Saying cishet people need to be careful how they use our terminology isnt the end of our identities that you are saying it is.
I will be the first to admit I am bad at Twitter, and agree with you, but idk how to untag you tbh 😅
Ah, yeah, so true. I /personally/ find context helpful (ex: “Queer Community” vs. “Queers”) mostly, but I can’t imagine how that feels for those who find the word hurtful.
To accept that people do resonate with this term and that other are actively harmed by having it used for them is where alienation is going to dissipate.

I can imagine that’s difficult, but at the end of the day, language and culture evolves and we have to accept that large groups of people now and in the future resonate with a queer community, which overlaps HEAVILY and is part of the LGBTQ community. 1/2

And cishet people have other umbrella terms they can use for those who do not identify as queer. Lgbt+ if they like, or whatever signifier the individual chooses. It’s just like pronouns. Ask, don’t assume, and respect the answers.

I have a friend who refers to himself using the f-slur. And I can’t bring myself to write the word, let alone say it. I would never tell him that he can’t use that for himself or subvert his efforts to reclaim it, and he knows to never call me that. It’s just mutual respect.

I think it’s more about looking at the word from the perspective of someone traumatized by having the word queer used as a slur against them. I like the term queer myself, and my community, but if someone else does not want to be associated with that label, I’d comply.

A jab, a hook being a swing of your fist that swings around from your side, and a jab being a fist that extends straight forward quickly. No matter what kind of punch you are throwing, remember to keep BOTH your hands up when you do. If you miss and your attacker retaliates 5/

Folded over the middle section of your fingers, and when you throw hands, the flat of your fist should be what connects. Your wrist should be straight and tensed, and your power should come from your shoulder and body, not your elbow. You will get more power with a hook than 4/

Cause you not to feel any injuries as they happen. ALSO! If you are throwing punches or putting your fists up against attackers, be mindful of your fist structure. Never fold your fingers over your thumb. Broken fingers are better than a broken thumb and if you connect your 2/
